story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAs it happened EndedFollow the latest business newsClick to followThe IndependentFood firms are urging the government to waive parts of competition law to allow them to work together to minimise disruption to supplies in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Meanwhile, the pound remains close to the 30-month low of $1.21 reached last week but is up slightly against the dollar and euro, despite news on Brexit appearing to worsen this morning.Senior Tory&nbspMPs&nbsphave suggested that the Queen may have to step in&nbspto&nbspuse prerogative powers to remove&nbspBoris Johnson as prime minister if he refused to step down after a potential no-confidence vote.Mr Johnson, whose government has a majority of just one MP, could face a no-confidence vote if he attempts to push through no-deal as promised on 31 October.Please allow the liveblog below a moment to load:Good morning and welcome to The Independent's live coverage of business and economics events around the world.&nbsp&nbspFood suppliers have warned that the UK would need 30 large empty warehouses to store even a week's extra food supply and there is currently no spare capacity in the country to deal with a chaotic Brexit in less than three months.&nbsp“In the event of no-deal disruption, if the Government wants the food supply chain to work together to tackle likely shortages - to decide where to prioritise shipments - they will have to provide cast-iron written reassurances that competition law will not be strictly applied to those discussions,” FDF's chief operating officer Tim Rycroft told the BBC.&nbspIn the markets, Asian stocks were down on Wednesday while European bourses gained in morning trading.&nbspDominic Raab, the foreign secretary, has&nbsppraised Donald Trump and his deputy Mike Pence for their warmth and enthusiasm for the UK-US relationship.&nbspRaab says he was delighted to meet the pair on his three-day trip to the US in hope of paving the way for a post-Brexit trade deal.The UK looks forward to working with our American friends to reach a free trade deal that is good for both countries, and co-operating on the common security challenges we face.&nbspE.On is the latest “Big Six” energy supplier to blame the government’s price cap for plummeting profits.The cap, which will be reduced this winter, is supposed to stop firms ripping off loyal customers.The German utility’s earnings from UK retail customers crashed 78 per cent in the latest quarter.Customer numbers fell by around 200,000 to 6.4 million in the three months to March.Bad news for E.On today but good news for about 15 million households who will see their energy bills fall this winter.&nbspAnnual energy bills will go down by £75 on average for 11 million households on standard tariffs and by £25 for customers who pay for their gas and electricity upfront.&nbspOfgem, the energy regulator for England, Wales and Scotland, is lowering the price caps for the October to March period due to lower wholesale energy prices.Full story here from Olesya Dmitracova:Energy bills to fall for 15 million households this winter as Ofgem lowers price capsExecutives at Hargreaves Lansdown will give up their bonuses after the Woodford fund fiasco, Reuters&nbspis reporting.&nbspAccording to the nes agency's source, Hargreaves' chief executive Chris Hill, Chief financial officer Philip Johnson, chief investment officer Lee Gardhouse and research director Mark Dampier, will take no bonus for 2019.&nbspHargreaves plugged Woodford's fund through its best buy list and received fees for referring customers.&nbspHundreds of thousands of Hargreaves Lansdown customers who ploughed their savings into Woodford's flagship fund have had their money frozen since June and it will likely stay there until at least December as the once highly regarded stock picker tries to sort out the mess he is in.&nbspWoodford invested in riskier unlisted stocks which he couldn't get rid of fast enough when a long run of poor performance prompted people to demands their cash back.House prices have fallen for the second successive month, Halifax says.The average UK house price was down 2 per cent in July to&nbsp£236,120 following a 0.4 per cent monthly decline in June.However, the lender said prices were still up 4.1 per cent in the year to July.Brexit uncertainty will weigh on the UK housing market over the next few months according to analysts at the EY ITEM Club.&nbspConsumers may well be particularly cautious about committing to buying a house, especially as house prices are relatively expensive relative to incomes, says Howard Archer.&nbspHouse prices are still far higher compared to earnings than the average over the last 35 years.&nbspAccording to the Halifax, the house price to earnings ratio was still as high as 5.59 in July after spiking to 5.72 in February (the highest level since November 2017) from 5.39 in January this is well above the long-term (1983-2019) average of 4.29.&nbspAnd it is questionable whether recent growth in jobs numbers and earnings can be sustained months as companies tailor their behaviour to a lacklustre domestic economy, prolonged Brexit uncertainties and a challenging global environment.&nbspTherefore Archer forecats&nbspthat house prices will rise by no more than 1.5 per cent in 2019.&nbsp&nbspTesla is in a spot of bother in the US.&nbspBloomberg&nbspreports that Elon Musk's firm has been scrutinised over safety claims on its Model 3 the car intended to take electric vehicles truly into the mainstream.&nbsp&nbspUS&nbspNational Highway Traffic Administration reportedly sent a cease and desist letter last year, taking issue with Tesla's&nbspclaim that the Model 3 had achieved the lowest probability of injury of any vehicle the agency ever tested.So, what exactly is Britain's food industry saying it needs the government to do to prevent food shortages after Brexit?&nbspIt's trade body wants firms&nbspto be allowed&nbspco-ordinate and direct supplies with each other if Britain crashes out of the EU on 31 October.&nbspThey cant do that under current rules which prevent them colluding. Those&nbspmeasures are designed to ensure adequate competition and result in the best outcome for consumers.The Food and Drink Federation (FDF) said: “We asked for these reassurances at the end of last year, but we're still waiting.”&nbspThe industry says that an October Brexit would be disastrous for food supplies because warehouses are already full in the run-up to Christmas.&nbsp&nbspOne retailer told the BBC that 31 October&nbsp“is about the worst day you can pick”, as warehouse capacity is at 105 per cent&nbspin November, versus 75 per cent - 80 per cent&nbspin March.The government isn't being entirely up-front about the potentially dire consequences of no-deal Brexit for fresh food and drink supplies, according to a leading academic on the topic.&nbspTim Lang, professor of food policy at City University, warned earlier this week that the UK’s food supply faces levels of disruption “unprecedented” in peacetime.&nbspWhat does that mean?&nbsp&nbsp	The government estimates that half of lorries entering the country will be unable to cross the border smoothly	The flow of trucks could drop by a third within a day of a no-deal Brexit	Food prices predicted to rise by more than 10 per cent as costs rise and supplies fall.Professor Lang warns&nbspthat Britons, particularly those on lower incomes, already under-consume fresh fruit and vegetables, and food banks are not fully prepared for shortages, which could have a negative impact on diets and public health.&nbspFull story here:&nbsp&nbspBrexit food shortages: Government being secretive over public health risks of no dealThousands of holidaymakers have had their flights cancelled due to more technology failures at British Airways.&nbspSimon Calder has counted&nbsp86 cancellations to and from Heathrow so far today, including one round-trip to New York and dozens of flights to Mediterranean resorts. A further 10 have been cancelled at Gatwick.&nbspThe full report, including details on which flights have been grounded and what you can do if you're affected, here:&nbspThousands of holidaymakers have had their flights cancelled and delayed&nbsp due to systems failuresWorrying figures out today suggest&nbspthat five million&nbsppension&nbspsavers could be susceptible to the common tactics used by scammers to steal retirement savings.&nbspPresented with six common scam scenarios, two-fifths of 45 to 65-year-olds said they would act in one or more ways which experts said could leave them exposed to fraud.&nbspThe data comes from a poll by the Financial Conduct Authority and the&nbspPensions Regulator.&nbspPeople should be wary of warning signs such as: pension&nbspcold calls, free&nbsppension&nbspreviews, claims of guaranteed high returns, exotic investments, time-limited offers, and promises of early access to cash.Back to potential food shortages after Brexit.&nbspWhat can consumers&nbspexpect? Unfortunately, even the food industry, which has tested a range of options to mitigate the effect of massive disruption at Dover, doesn't really know.&nbspFood and Drink Federation boss Tim Rycroft tells the BBC:&nbsp&nbspThere will be selective shortages and they will to some extent be random because it depends on which trucks get through and which don't. We think there will be some serious disruption and it will go on for weeks or months after our exit.The government is unlikely to grant the food industry's wish for&nbsprelaxed rules to alleviate food supply problems, says Mark Jones, partner at law firm Gordons. Big supermarkets&nbspprobably won't&nbspbe on board either.Jones says: “The ‘big four’ control almost 70 per cent&nbspof the market and if any of them have a supply chain advantage post-Brexit, it offers them an opportunity to gain market share, says Jones.&nbspI cannot see them wanting to help their competitors. They will want to help their own customers.&nbsp&nbsp“As to suppliers, if they can sell the stock they have, they will, and they may well be able to make a better profit if supply is tight. &nbspIf they cannot sell or use their raw materials, there is nothing stopping them picking up the phone to their competitors and selling raw materials now. &nbspRelaxing rules on anti-competitive behaviour is, in my view, unlikely to help shortages and I cannot see the Government going for it.”&nbspThe pound is a quarter of a per cent lower against the dollar so far today at $1.2137, not far off the 31-month low of $1.2080 it hit last week.&nbspAgainst the euro, sterling is down 0.1 of a cent, leaving it slightly above the 23-month low reached yesterday.&nbspWith little to look out for on the economic calendar, Connor Cambell, financial analyst at Spreadex, predicts markets will remain incredibly susceptible to the minutiae of the trade war and comments from Donald Trump.Twitter has revealed it may have used some people's personal data to target them with advertising without their permission because of issues within the platform's settings, the&nbspPress Association&nbspreports.The social media giant said it had recently discovered issues in its website where settings choices may not have worked as intended, resulting in some gathered data being used to personalise advertising.Twitter said it fixed the issues on 5 August.In a blog post discussing the problems, Twitter detailed how, in one case, data may have been shared with advertisers despite not receiving user permission to do so.Donald Trump's trade war with China has pushed oil prices to a new seven-month low as the outlook for the global economy looks increasingly bleak.&nbspBrent crude is down 0.6&nbspper cent to $58.31.&nbspThe US president attacked Beijing this week for allegedly manipulating its currency to make Chinese exports more competitive.&nbsp&nbspThe UK government is yet to respond to a request by the food industry to waive parts of competition law so that companies can cooperate after a no-deal&nbspBrexit&nbspto mitigate&nbspfood shortages.&nbspFull story from title: galaxy note 10 samsung review gear vr bixby virtual reality
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsNeither the Bixby&nbspsmart assistant nor virtual reality made an appearance at Samsung's latest tech showcaseClick to followThe Independent TechSamsung unveiled the world's most powerful smartphones in New York this week, in the form of the Galaxy Note 10 and the Note 10+, alongside its vision for the future of personal electronics.Company CEO DJ Koh&nbspstressed the value of 5G, augmented reality and even high-tech styluses in his presentation, summed up by the tagline: Experience Innovation. But there were two technologies that were notably absent from the Unpacked event.Neither Samsung's virtual assistant Bixby nor VR compatibility for the Note 10&nbspreceived a single mention during the nearly two-hour tech&nbspshowcase. Both have been heavily hyped in recent years, but their quiet omission&nbspsuggests they may no longer be central to Samsung's grander ambitions.Bixby has not been forgotten entirely, with both the Note 10 and Note 10+ supporting the virtual assistant. But Samsung's answer to Apple's Siri and Amazon's Alexa was not called upon or showed off during any of the product demos.At the same venue in 2018, Samsung unveiled the Bixby-supported Galaxy Home, which was designed to offer an alternative to other smart speakers like the Amazon Echo, Apple HomePod and Google Home. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsDisney CEO says company will update the franchiseClick to followThe Independent CultureMacaulay Culkin has reacted to the news of a possible&nbspHome Alone&nbspreboot with a hilarious rendition of what his character Kevin McCallister would be up to nowadays.It was reported&nbspearlier this week that Disney is planning on rebooting the franchise, which began in 1990 with the first&nbspHome Alone&nbspfilm.“This is what an updated Home Alone would actually look like,” Culkin, now 38, tweeted, along with a photo of himself posing as a contemporary Kevin.While in the original, Kevin originally uses his newfound freedom to eat ice cream (among other snacks) in front of the TV, this modern version is digging into some sort of pasta dish with a laptop on his lap.He’s surrounded with more Tupperware boxes of food, as well as a Playstation controller, a stack of papers and a couple of remotes.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Best films of 2019 (so far) Show all 26Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.“Gloria Bell is somewhat exhausting – both unbearably intimate and at a constant remove – but it is endlessly pulled back into focus by Moore, who has a firm understanding of the delicate balance between contentment and yearning, joy and pain, recklessness and spontaneity. In a remake that could have felt indulgent in the hands of people less skilled, she more than justifies its existence.”“Late Night is a caustic satirical comedy that turns into an unlikely tearjerker. It’s by turns snide and uplifting, and often very funny too. Its writerproducerstar Mindy Kaling makes vicious observations about the inanity, narcissism and corruption of the mainstream US media at the same time as she celebrates the professionalism of many of those who work within it.“Olivia Wilde is a visually inventive director, who keeps the tempo here so brisk that we hardly notice how glib the storytelling sometimes becomes. We can tell exactly how the film will end, but it still feels original both in its screwball energy and in the deft way it continually reverses stereotypes and gender clichés.” “Macabre and fraught though The Favourite gets, this isn’t so much a film about sex or power as it is about plain mischief. It’s a hilarious, buffoonish pleasure, right down to the sets and costume design, and a breeze to spend 120 minutes with.” Christopher Hooton“Casting Chalamet as Nic was a very clever move. The young actor from Call Me by Your Name and Lady Bird has a natural charm and charisma. He still engages an audience’s curiosity and sympathy even when his behaviour is at its most selfish and erratic.” Geoffrey Macnab626 The House by the Sea“Guédiguian’s storytelling style is deceptive. McKay isn’t only taking us through Cheney’s life and career but is giving us a whistle stop tour through US politics from the Nixon administration almost right to the present day.” Geoffrey Macnab“Playing Lee Israel, McCarthy manages something very special: she makes a character who is odd, obnoxious, difficult and alcoholic seem lovable and even heroic. It deals with racism and homophobia but still has a fairytale, fantasy feel to it. Whatever humiliations Don endures on their road trip, we know no real harm will ever come to him as long as Tony is at his side.” Geoffrey Macnab“The golden age of bonkers horror movies is gloriously evoked by Netflix’s latest feature length presentation. Beginning as a satire of the arts world, Velvet Buzzsaw swiftly and gleefully descends into a savage splatter-fest, smeared in paint, viscera and garishly-bright blood.” Ed Power“Written by Ben Elton and directed by its star Kenneth Branagh, the film plays so fast and loose with the playwright’s final years that they needn’t have bothered fitting Branagh with a prosthetic nose – accuracy is clearly not the priority here.” Alexandra PollardThe Lego Movie 2: The Second Part is the doomed progeny of a celebrated genius – brilliant but slightly stunted by the knowledge they will never live up to their predecessor.” Clarisse Loughrey“Nicolas Pesce’s sleek and stylish horror comedy is repulsive and funny by turns. In adapting Ryu Murakami’s cult novel, Pesce strikes just the right balance between humour and Grand Guignol-style shock tactics.” Geoffrey MacnabThe best moments here are remarkable. Labaki elicits an astonishing performance from her young lead. He’s an irrepressible figure with such an inbuilt sense of moral decency the film seems upbeat and optimistic, even at its darkest moments.” Geoffrey MacnabRalph Fiennes combines thriller elements with poetic flashbacks to ballet legend Rudolf Nureyev’s childhood and keeps a tight focus on the dancer. When he is most at risk, Nureyev makes decisions with his artistic future more in mind than his personal safety. As Fiennes reminds us again and again in what is his best film yet as a director, the 'white crow' will do anything to put himself in the limelight, the one place he is convinced he belongs.Border reverses the perspective taken by most other horror films. In more conventional genre fare, Tina and Vore would be portrayed as malevolent outsiders, but in the world conjured up by director Ali Abbasi, the humans are the monsters. Tina is the innocent – a visionary who hardly understands her own powers but who can sense human venality and corruption wherever it appears.1926 Fighting with My FamilyCertain scenes feel very trite and predictable but the film gets you in a choke hold early on and won’t let you go. It is far more gripping than its subject matter might suggest. Who ever would believe a story about a wrestling family from Norwich could have quite such heart and resonance?Doppelgangers abound in Jordan Peele’s weird, creepy and ingenious new horror film. As in his Oscar-winning 2017 feature Get Out, Peele leavens matters with ironic humour but the joking becomes increasingly uncomfortable once the main characters come face to face with dark shadows of themselves which wish them extreme harm.The Avengers cycle comes to a rich and very satisfying conclusion with Endgame, surely the most complex and emotional superhero movie in Marvel history. At 181 minutes, this is a veritable epic, but with so many characters and plot strands, it fully warrants its lengthy running time.It’s a rare and precious feeling when a film completely dismantles you. title: pound live dollar euro exchange rate brexit no deal gbp usd
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAs it happened EndedFollow the latest business updatesClick to followThe IndependentThe pound is set to fall even further as the likelihood increases of a no-deal Brexit that will be disastrous for the UK economy, according to a poll.Sterling has already suffered a rout since Boris Johnson became prime minister on 24 July, falling to a two-and-a-half year low against the dollar of $1.2080 last week.Analysts polled by Reuters predicted further declines to between $1.17 and $1.20 as the 31 October deadline day approaches.Please allow a moment for the live blog to loadPound to be worth less than dollar for first time ever after no-deal Brexit, analyst forecastsGood morning and welcome to The Independent's live coverage of business and economics events around the world.&nbsp&nbspAnalysts are predicting that the pound, already battered by Boris Johnson's premiership, is set to fall further in the coming weeks.&nbspHouse prices are also suffering in the Brexit gloom, according to a poll of surveyors.Looking beyond pound v dollar, things are even worse for the pound.&nbspAgainst a trade-weighted basket of major currencies, sterling hit a 33-month low on 30 July&nbspSterling’s recent tumble suggests that a no-deal Brexit could take the pound into uncharted territory, says&nbspSilvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management.&nbspAgainst the dollar, that could mean $1.05 to $1.10 but, Given the tendency for financial markets to overshoot, no-deal Brexit could easily push the pound to parity with the dollar which has never happened before.&nbspShe adds:&nbspGoing forward, there is scope for wider ranges of value for the pound, including the possibility of an increase if MPs are able to successfully block a no-deal Brexit in Parliament, but realistically, the next few months don’t hold much promise for the currency. &nbspSeptember and October could be wildly volatile months for sterling.&nbspWhat would the economy look like after a no-deal Brexit with&nbspone&nbsppound worth less than one dollar?&nbspPretty dreadul, according to Silvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management:&nbspA sharp currency depreciation would act as a supply-side shock, driving a spike in inflation, a squeeze on income and a drag on consumption. Savings would fail to provide an ample buffer as consumers have already dissaved significantly since the EU referendum. In fact, the saving rate is running close to its record low levels.&nbsp&nbspBusiness investment may also slow further as a falling pound with potential for further depreciation could spook investors. Furthermore, the benefit of rising exports usually associated with a weaker currency has not yet been felt by UK businesses, which suggests we may see little boost to exports from a weak pound.&nbspSome better news today in stock markets that have suffered recently from fears surrounding an escalating trade war between the US&nbspand China.&nbspThe major indices edged up on the back of&nbspsurprise news that Chinese exports rose 3.3 per cent in July, despite rising tariffs imposed by Donald Trump's administration.&nbspImports were also up suggesting China is showing signs of resilience.&nbsp&nbsp- Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.37 per cent to 20,593.35.&nbsp- Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 0.5 per cent to 26,120.77&nbsp- Germany's Dax up 0.5 per cent to 11,712.12&nbsp- France's CAC 40 up 1 per cent to 5,317.74&nbsp- FTSE 100 up 0.14 per cent to 7,208.62While interest rates and economic data would normally drive the value of the pound, right now the primary factor by a long distance is the perceived probability that the UK will leave the EU with no deal on 31 October.&nbspThe more likely it appears to be, the lower the pound goes.&nbspThis morning brings news of another plan MPs have hatched to prevent that outcome, which a majority of them - and the public - want to avoid.&nbspMPs are considering a bid to cancel the annual autumn recess set aside for party conferences in a fresh attempt to prevent Boris Johnson ploughing ahead with a no-deal Brexit, our political correspondent Ashley Cowburn reports.&nbspBrexit: MPs considering bid to ‘cancel autumn recess’ to stop Halloween no-dealBrexit has put some people off buying or selling a home, says upmarket estate agent Savills, which reported results today.&nbspSales of UK property are at the lowest level since the financial crisis while protests in Hong Kong also dented the market there, Savills says.&nbspChief executive&nbspMark Ridley: “In many markets, particularly the UK and Hong Kong, political and economic uncertainty has considerably reduced the volume of real estate trading activity in recent months, although occupier demand remains robust.&nbspHalf-year pre-tax profits fell 12 per cent to £38.4m in the six months to 30 June.&nbspA plummeting pound of course means reduced spending power&nbspfor British holidaymakers heading away this month.&nbspAs always, even the best rates for consumers are some way below the market rate.&nbsp&nbspAt the best of the large foreign exchange providers, £750 will now buy you:&nbspeuros:&nbspDebenhams - €801.75M&ampS Bank - €801Post Office - €800.25&nbspor, for dollars:&nbspDebenhams - $898.50Post Office - $897Sainsbury’s Bank - $897Figures courtesy of MoneyHargreaves Lansdown doesn't seem to have been hurt too badly by its involvement in the Neil Woodford fund scandal that has seen hundreds of thousands of customers unable to access their money.&nbspThe fund supermarket recommended Woodford's now-suspended fund through its best buy lists.&nbspIt says today that inflows of client funds have held up well since Woodford froze clients' cash in early June.Troubling reading in the UN's climate change report released today which says that humans need to urgently change their diets to avoid catastrophic levels of global warming.&nbspThat will mean huge changes for the agriculture&nbspand food&nbspindustries.&nbspVicki Hird from Sustain, a British charity which advocates better food and farming, says: “The IPCC report proposes adopting farming practices that work with nature rather than forcing production with overuse of artificial fertilisers. &nbspA key step would be to end harmful subsidies of big single crops (such as corn, sugar cane, soy) and fossil fuels.”&nbspFull report here from science correspondent Phoebe Weston:&nbsp'A perfect storm': People must change diet and stop destroying land before it is too late, says major climate change report&nbspThe FTSE-100 index is up 19.42 at 7218.12.&nbspThe pound is broadly flat so far today against both the euro and dollar.Liz Truss, the UK’s international trade secretary, is speaking to the right-wing US think tank the Heritage Foundation today about a trade deal with the US.The ultra-free-market organisation is committed to cutting environmental regulations and other protections.Ms Truss met privately with the group last year, documents obtained by Greenpeace’s investigative unit Unearthed&nbsprevealed this week.Among the topics discussed were “what we can learn from ‘Reaganomics’ on things like regulation and red tape”.More bad Brexit news for homeowners?The&nbspUK housing market&nbspis stuck in a holding pattern as buyers wait for more clarity on&nbspBrexit&nbspbefore committing to a purchase that could prove unwise if Britain crashes out of the EU in October, reports Olesya Dmitracova.Political and economic uncertainty has driven UK residential transactions at Savills to their lowest level since the financial crisis, the estate agency, one of the nation’s largest, said in its half-year earnings report on Thursday.&nbspA fall in home sales was also revealed in the July survey by the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors, and earlier this week Halifax said sales had dropped during the early months of the summer.Full report here:Housing market loses momentum as UK inches closer to no-deal BrexitNationwide is returning £6m to more than&nbsp320,000 of its customers after the Competition and Markets Authority found that the bank had failed to alert the customers before charging them for unarranged overdrafts.&nbspThe CMA introduced an order in February last year stating that bank customers with personal current accounts must receive a text alert before the charges can be levied. title: taylor swift kim kardashian kanye west feud vogue interview public shaming
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe singersongwriter also revealed to Vogue why she decided to go public with her politics and support for&nbspLGBTQ+ rightsClick to followThe Independent CultureTaylor Swift has claimed&nbspshe was the victim of “mass public shaming” following her high-profile feud with Kim Kardashian and Kanye West.Speaking to Vogue, Swift explained that the trio’s heavily-publicised fall out, and the subsequent criticism sent her way, left her feeling isolated and humiliated. “A mass public shaming, with millions of people saying you are quote-unquote cancelled, is a very isolating experience,” she revealed. “I don’t think there are that many people who can actually understand what it’s like to have millions of people hate you very loudly.”She continued: “When you say someone is cancelled, it’s not a TV show. It’s a human being. You’re sending mass amounts of messaging to this person to either shut up, disappear, or it could also be perceived as, Kill yourself. I realised I needed to restructure my life because it felt completely out of control. I knew immediately I needed to make music about it because I knew it was the only way I could survive it. It was the only way I could preserve my mental health and also tell the story of what it’s like to go through something so humiliating.”Created with Sketch.From beef to BFFs to beef again: Kanye West and Taylor Swift Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 13:   Kanye West (L) jumps onstage after Taylor Swift (C) won the Best Female Video award during the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards at Radio City Music Hall on September 13, 2009 in New York City. I made that bitch famous'Kim Kardashian releases of audio of Tayior Swift approving the lyrics to 'Famous'In the same interview, Swift also declared her eagerness to become more politically active after an incident with one of her best friends (dancer Todrick Hall)&nbspmade her realise her silence about political subjects had been a problem.Charli XCX says Taylor Swift comments were taken ‘out of context’Katy Perry hopes end of Taylor Swift feud will inspire girlsWhy Taylor Swift’s new LGBT-themed video isn’t as woke as it looks“Maybe a year or two ago, Todrick and I are in the car, and he asked me, 'What would you do if your son was gay?'” she recalled. “The fact that he had to ask me shocked me and made me realise that I had not made my position clear enough or loud enough. If my son was gay, he’d be gay. I don’t understand the question.”She added, “Rights are being stripped from basically everyone who isn’t a straight white cisgender male. I didn’t realise until recently that I could advocate for a community that I’m not a part of. It’s hard to know how to do that without being so fearful of making a mistake that you just freeze. Because my mistakes are very loud. When I make a mistake, it echoes through the canyons of the world. title: brexit politics party conference autumn recess cancel mps
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Politics Explained: MPs could vote to cancel the annual autumn recess for constitutional battles over Brexit,&nbspbut how will his affect gatherings of the party faithful?Click to followIndy PoliticsIn the latest attempt to stop Boris Johnson forcing through a no-deal Brexit&nbspin just over two-and-a-half months, MPs are now said to be considering extending the parliamentary time available for more constitutional battles in the House of Commons.The proposed suggestion is that when MPs return revitalised from their summer break, rebels will turn their attention to amending the usually mundane motion required for the the chamber to break once again in mid-September for the annual party conference season.Typically, Westminster goes into recess during this period for three weeks and returns in October. It occurs so that MPs can decamp the Commons chamber and travel to gatherings of party members across the country.&nbspLeaders of all the main parties use the major event in the political calendar to set out their policy agenda and vision for the future, while thousands of activists gather in the conference halls.If MPs do decide to cancel the autumn recess, however, it is almost certain the conferences themselves will go ahead – not least due to them being a major source of income for the political parties.&nbspCreated with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A mosque is seen amongst residential housing from the air during a mass take off at the annual Bristol hot air balloon festival in BristolAn Asiatic lioness eats meat during feeding time ahead of World Lion Day at London ZooBeer enthusiasts taste beer and ale during The Great British Beer Festival at Kensington Olympia in west London. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAngry row after John McDonnell says Labour will not&nbspblock Scottish independence referendumClick to followIndy PoliticsScottish Labour has fired off a warning to Jeremy Corbyn&nbspto express serious concerns over deepening splits&nbspon&nbspthe party's stance on independence.In a sternly worded statement, the MSPs said they deplore any attempts to undermine the official position of the Scottish party and they expect all Scottish Labour MPs and MSPs to join in opposing&nbspa second referendum on Scotland's membership of the United Kingdom.John McDonnell set himself at odds with the party's Scottish leader Richard Leonard&nbspwhen he told an audience at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival on Monday that Labour would not block a new&nbspScottish independence referendum.Amid a furious backlash, the shadow chancellor reaffirmed his position that Labour&nbsprisked falling into a trap “set up” by the SNP to blame the “big bad English” for&nbspblocking their plans.The row evokes previous clashes in Labour ranks. Former Scottish leader Johann Lamont famously accused Ed Miliband of treating the party north of the border&nbspas a branch office when she resigned in 2014.Created with Sketch.Boris Johnson's resigned as international development secretaryDavid Lidlington resigned as deputy Prime MinisterPhilip Hammond resigned as Chancellor of the ExchequerIn a statement on Thursday, the Scottish Labour Parliamentary party made&nbspclear its opposition to another isive and unnecessary referendum on independence.The group said: We deplore any attempts to undermine the official policy position of the Scottish Labour party and we express serious concerns about an apparent change in Labour's position on a matter of vital importance to the future of Scotland and of the Scottish Labour party itself.Scottish party policy is very clear - that is opposition to a second independence referendum.There is therefore an urgent need for the UK party leadership to engage constructively with the Scottish party leadership on the issue of the party's stance on the future of Scotland.How could Scotland secure a second independence referendum?McDonnell stance on Scottish independence causes major Labour riftAnti-Brexit campaigners to target 100 seats at next general electionIt added: We are clear Labour's position on Scotland's future is a decision for Scottish Labour, which the UK party must accept.We expect all Scottish Labour MPs and MSPs to vote in accordance with party policy.Labour’s 2017&nbspelection manifesto claimed independence in Scotland would “lead to turbocharged austerity for Scottish families”.Mr Leonard, who is an ally of the Labour leader, said he had spoken to the shadow chancellor on Wednesday to set out his&nbspposition on the issue.Their conversation came&nbspafter Mr McDonnell doubled down on his stance, saying: I'm not being set up by Nicola Sturgeon to blame the UK government for blocking the will of the Scottish people - that's too trite a political manoeuvre that's been taken on at the moment.In the situation we're in at the moment, my view is that we will not be blocking a proposal.The best way forward in all of this is to elect a Labour government. We'll demonstrate what we can do and then I think the Scottish people won't be interested in another referendum.But if they ever do come back, my view is you can't be in a situation where you block it.It comes as a recent poll by Lord Ashcroft&nbspgave a lead for Scottish independence for the first time since 2017, with 52 cent of Scottish people in favour and 48 per cent against.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Morgan hit 17 sixes and set a new record in one-day international cricket, which saw his side win by 150 runsEconomists agree that the housing market will suffer if Britain leaves the EU without a deal.&nbspThe government’s spending watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), forecast last month that house prices would tumble by almost 6 per cent in 2020 and another 3 per cent in 2021. The slide could be even steeper as the OBR’s prediction was based on the assumption of a particular type of no-deal Brexit – the less disruptive of the two laid out by the IMF earlier this year.Howard Archer, economic adviser to the EY Item&nbspClub, forecasts a similar decline, saying house prices would quickly fall by about 5 per cent as the economy weakened and the market was mired in acute uncertainty over Britain’s future trading relationship with the EU.For now, house prices look on track for hardly any growth over this year.&nbspAccording to RICS, a net balance of 9 per cent of respondents reported a fall in average prices over the past three months in England and Wales. Samuel Tombs, economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said the result is consistent with the official measure of prices showing a rise of only 0.5 per cent in 2019.&nbspHalifax data also showed that UK house prices dropped slightly in July for the second consecutive month and now stand at £236,120 on average.“The market continues to tread water,” said Russell Galley, managing director at Halifax.&nbsp“In the longer term, we believe there is unlikely to be a step change in market activity until buyers and sellers see some form of resolution to the current economic uncertainty.”RICS echoed this prediction, noting that its survey now points to zero growth in sales – as well as a steeper fall in prices – in the next three months.On Thursday Boris Johnson reiterated his trademark message that Britain will leave the EU on 31 October, even though no progress has been made on securing a withdrawal agreement acceptable to both sides.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: eid mubarak meaning greeting reply eid al adha eid
story: You may have heard some people using the phrase: Eid Mubarak, but what does the greeting translate as and is there a specic way to reply Eid Mubarak is a traditional Muslim greeting reserved for the holy festivals of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.Eid means celebration and mubarak means blessed.The saying can be translated as have a blessed holiday.It is then customary to reply Khair Mubarak.This reciprocates good wishes in the hope they will also have a blessed holiday.The celebration of Eid al-Adha begins in the evening on August , , and end four days later on Saturday, August .Eid-al-Fitr follows a month of fasting for Ramadan in June.Eid celebrations continue for dferent s of time in dferent cultures.In Qatar, for example, they celebrate for  days. While Oman enjoys a nine-day party.In the Islamic lunar calendar, Eid al-Adha takes place on the th day of the th month and lasts for four days until the th day.Muslims begin their celebrations with morning prayers, followed by food and exchanging of gts with family and friends.They also share their food and money with the poor so that they can celebrate too. Eid or Eid al-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, which is a month of fastingEid kickstarts the month of Shawwal, which begins with a feast to end the period of fasting.The celebration is a public holiday in many Muslim countries, but is not one in the UK, despite a campaign for it to be recognised back in .Eid means celebration and Mubarak means blessed, often Eid Mubarak is used as a greeting over this period.In  Eid al-Fitr will begin on the evening of June  and ends the following night.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains got talent stalker miss england
story: But making her way to her proud parents, her joy suddenly turned to terror as a man lurking backstage violently grabbed her body and tried to pull her in for a kiss, murmuring: Youre beautul.Samantha, then , realised with horror who it was - Britains Got Talent rapper Jonathan Deal, whod spent months bombarding her with creepy messages on Facebook.Deal, , launched a terrying campaign of harassment against the model after falling in love with her online - following her to events all over the UK and even pinning her against a wall in a rage.This time, hed stalked her  miles from Dorset to the  Miss England finals in Nottingham, where hed posed as her boyfriend, tried to sit on her familys table and laid in wait for her backstage.Now, Samantha has spoken exclusively to Sun Online as Deal has been caged for  weeks for breaching a restraining order, saying she fears he will kill her when he is freed.The stalker has already served time for harassing her and has a shocking rap sheet of  similar previous offences.She tells us how the obsessed fans actions left her so traumatised she had to sleep at the bottom of her parents bed, was too scared of men to date and even hired bodyguards to protect her. I was constantly looking over my shoulder and was never on my own - I always had someone with me to ensure I was safe and even hired private security to keep me safe, recalls Samantha, now .“I wasnt sleeping and ended up staying in mum and dads room in my mid-s. I had to sleep at the bottom of their bed. I didn’t eat properly because I felt sick at the thought of everything that went on and was scared of him contacting me again.She adds: I dont feel safe when Deals out of prison... he could come out, go off the radar and try to hurt me - or worse, kill me. It’s happened before in other stalking cases so Im scared.Deals  past offences relate to other harassment and stalking incidents dating back to  - and Samantha fears more women could be targeted by the rapper when hes released.On one hand Im so happy hes away [again], but on the other hand Im like  weeks - really  He should get years after everything hes put me and the other girls through, she tells us.When he came out of prison the first time my anxiety went through the roof and I was in and out of the doctors and not sleeping.The beauty queens hellish ordeal started innocently enough.Wannabe star Deal - who goes by the stage name JAYD - added her on Facebook like hundreds of her other fans.I had a friend request on Facebook around June , but thought nothing of it, says Samantha, who was crowned Miss Poole  and Miss Dorset . I have lots of supporters, so I accepted it.Yet it soon became clear Deal wasnt an ordinary fan.He began besieging her with unwanted messages, shared pictures of her in a wedding dress with an engagement ring emoji, and bizarrely vowed to dedicate his BGT audition song to her.He also started turning up to events she was at - including SandFest music festival in Poole, Dorset, last July, where he asked the model for a photo together.He just appeared and tapped me on the shoulder, Samantha recalls.He said Hi Sam, its Jonathan Deal. I was like Oh hello, thinking in my head it was weird. Id never met him and for him to just turn up was really, really weird.She adds: I then got this message on Facebook: really nice to meet you.Obviously I replied, really nice to meet you too. I was being polite.The moment Samantha shared anything on Facebook, Deal would like or comment on it.Then last September, the rapper tried to gatecrash a VIP tent Samantha was in at the Bournemouth Air Festival - and posted a live blog on Facebook claiming he was in love with her.The same month, he turned up at the Miss England finals at Nottinghams prestigious Kelham Hall, where Samantha made the top  and was crowned Miss South Coast Charity Queen after attending more than  charity events in  months.It was here he disturbingly told people he was her boyfriend, before lunging in to kiss her backstage.I felt like a real-le princess that night, says Samantha, now a teaching assistant.I had a real diamond tiara on my head, worth £,, and I had a dress on that was stunning.She adds: Out the back, theres a little arch we walk through - Deal literally grabbed me and went to hug me and kiss my lips. I felt physically sick - his breath near mine made me shiver.It was a huge moment and he ruined it.Samantha managed to push her stalker off before fleeing to find her parents.But when she told them what had just happened, she was sickened to discover that Deal had been wandering around looking for her and had even tried to sit at her familys table to get close to her.They hadnt seen him [lunge at me] but I said, hes just tried to kiss me, she says.They said, the moment its finished, were leaving. We had to sneak out the back.Deal later told Samantha she only did well because the judges thought you were my girlfriend.And it wouldnt be the last time he confronted her.While Samantha blocked the stalker on Facebook straight after the Miss England final, she claims he later turned up at her work, pinned her against a wall and yelled: Unblock me! Unblock me!He also posted about her all over social media.Someone like myself who is always smiling and positive, [the harassment] caused me a lot of anxiety and stress, resulting in me having to go to the doctors a lot, Samantha says.I’ve been single over a year as I just haven’t been in the right headspace.It’s massively put me off going on and dating sites because I just don’t know who they and for all I know they could be him or people like him.Finally, after a three-month nightmare, the beauty queen reported Deal to police and he was arrested for his harassment campaign.But during the rappers court case, the model - who is also an ambassador for UK non-profit Help  Homeless Veterans - was distraught to learn that she was far from his only victim.I remember it so well, he was talking about his previous [ offences], she tells us.My dad grabbed my hand and I just cried in his arms in the courtroom.At this point I was adamant this guy is a sick freak.While Deal was out on bail, under strict conditions, Samantha says she rang police at all hours of the day in a state of terror, using a special panic phone shed been given.Dorset Police were absolutely incredible, they were at my beck and call, says Samantha, who became so stressed that she ended up on medication. I called them twice a day sometimes, panicking.She was relieved when, in February, Deal was finally caged for  weeks and handed an indefinite restraining order banning him from any form of contact with her, after he admitted harassment.But Samanthas stress ed only three months later when she discovered the con had been freed early, on May .Id felt so good knowing he was behind bars - there was no way he could stalk me or anyone near me - [but] after he was released I struggled, she says.I had a special doorbell fitted in my familys house. The doorbell rings and we can see whos at the door - andsomeone walks past the door we can see them.She adds: I was going round the house locking all the doors.Incredibly, on May , just four days after his release, Deal broke the terms of his restraining order by re-posting messages on Facebook relating to the Miss Dorset and Miss England contests Samantha had participated in.The rapper was hauled before Poole Magistrates Court last month, where he was convicted of two counts of breaching the order and sent back to prison for  weeks.But Samantha fears his short sentence means he could soon terrorise someone  - and has backed calls for a national stalking register to protect women from predators like Deal.The moment you come across Jonathan Deal, block him, she warns.Dont give him the time of day or a chance. Im that person who gave him a chance. I thought, Oh hes lovely, this will be OK. I should have blocked him a lot earlier.She adds: If there was a register, Deal would have been known and dealt with a lot quicker.Later this year, Stalking Protection Orders- backed by The Sun - will come into effect to help protect victims.More than one in five women and almost one in  men aged  to  have been victims of stalking since the age of , according to the Crime Survey for England and Wales.SPOs will prevent stalkers from contacting victims or approaching them through those around them - and will force them to register their name, address and any aliases they use.Offenders may also be banned from ­loitering near victims’ homes.A breach of the order will be punishable by up to five years behind bars.Today, while Deal languishes in jail, Samantha is looking ahead to the Miss Sovereign GB pageant - a contest that aims to empower girls and women while raising funds for charity.She decided to enter the pageant to help others and raise awareness of stalking - but is understandably taking a very dferent approach towards social media and her fans.I havent added anyone that I dont know recently and that is big for me, Samantha says. If I havent met you, you cant be on my Facebook. I need to know who you are.As for Deal, she adds that shell always worry about him.Someone like him doesnt give up - its sickening, she says.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk area 51 what storm facebook alien
story: ButBrits want to don tin foil hats and look for evidence of extraterrestrials in the UK, where should they go The Facebook plan to storm the American base to see them aliens began as a joke which is now being taken seriously — deadly seriously.Not only did Facebook pull down the page, the Air Force issued a chilling warning to potential raiders that: The US Air Force always stands ready to protect America and its assets.Its not known exactly what secrets the shadowy base has that authorities are desperate to defend.Ufologists — who study unidentied flying objects — believe the site holds alien spacecraft being studied for their technology, a claim famously repeated by a former engineer at the site, Bob Lazar.But conspiracy theorists in the UK dont need to look as far afield as the States for mysterious government facilities linked with UFOs.Nick Pope ran the Ministry of Defences UFO project in the s, looking into reports of flying saucers, crop circles, and even abductions. Here he reveals the secret spots that might be Britains Area . RAF Rudloe Manor, WiltshireTheory: Alien technology being kept in secret underground labFor years, conspiracy theorists believed the government was hiding something at RAF Rudloe Manor in Corsham, Wiltshire.And to some extent, they were right — documents made public in  admitted that the base WAS used in UFO investigations.Thats because Rudloe Manor was home to the Flying Complaints Flight, a unit of the RAF Police which gathered reports of UFO sightings from RAF bases and passed them to the MoD HQ.And the secret site came under even more scrutiny when it was revealed there was a vast network of underground tunnels beneath the base.Ufologists had suspected this for years but instead of the tunnels being used to hide alien technology they were nuclear bomb shelters.The vast subterranean bunkers would be where government ministers and royals wouldve been evacuated tothere was a nuclear strike on Britain.Even though Rudloe Manor was closed in , it still attracts conspiracy theorists — some have been arrested by MoD Police for breaking in.Nick himself had a brush with the authorities when he was filming a documentary there with presenter Giorgio Tsoukalos a few years ago.He said: As a former MoD employee I didn’t feel it was appropriate for me to approach the site, so Giorgio went alone.Within moments, military police turned up and halted filming, further fuelling the conspiracy theories.Ministry of Defence Main Building, LondonTheory: UFO investigations team officially shutdown but still running in secretInside Room  in the MoD Main Building in Whitehall, the governments main UFO project looked into the strange reports of flying saucers around the UK.In the  years the project ran until , around , cases were looked into by the team.Although most were debunked, around five per cent of the cases couldnt be explained.And although the project was officially closed down a decade ago, Nick believes it still operating but now in secret.He claims a source in the MoD told him Americans were now running the project.And another told him investigations have just moved to a new part of the building where the investigators are jokingly referred to as Mulder and Scully.Nick even says protesters have already turned up at the site to demand answers in October .He said: It wasn’t quite on the scale of what’s threatened for Area .Around  people assembled outside Parliament and then marched over to Main Building, waving signs that said ‘UFOs are real’, before handing in a letter demanding an end to UFO secrecy.I’d left the UFO project by then, but they somehow got hold of my new phone number and I had to meet them and formally take possession of their letter.The National Archives, KewTheory: Sensitive documents about aliens kept secret after sham public releaseThe UK’s National Archives in Kew are the final repository of the MoD’s real-le X-Files.Last year, declassied files there showed the government had spent  years looking into UFOs in the hope we could steal alien technology to develop super weapons during the Cold War.The once-secret files showed UFOs were real and being taken seriously.They also detailed near misses between RAF aircraft and UFOs which posed a dangerous threat to the crews safety.The first load of these files was made public in the National Archives in  — and Nick was enlisted to help with their publicity.And over the next  years, more and more information came out, but some files were still redacted.This made some people think the government was holding information back.But Nick says: The blacked-out material is often just names and addresses of UFO witnesses, withheld to protect people’s privacy.If people could see the uncensored files, all people will find out is that Mr Smith of  Acacia Avenue saw a UFO while out walking his dog sometime back in !RAE Farnborough, HampshireTheory: Site of alien abductions is primary location where alien tech would be keptThe Royal Aerospace Establishment at Farnborough, Hampshire has previously been called Britain’s Area .RAE Farnborough was originally set up as an aircraft and weapons research facility at the turn of the twentieth century and closed in the late s.In , a y report by conspiracy theorists claimed the site was well-connected to UFO sightings — and even alien abductions.Rumours persist, and Farnborough is currently home to QinetiQ, a defence technology company that researches and develops cutting-edge equipment including weapons, robotics and space-related tech.And Nick saysthe UK ever did get hold of extraterrestrial tech, it probably wouldve been sent to Farnborough for study.But he also wants to pour cold water on the claims that the site ever did have alien tech — as he had a close relationship with someone who knew for a fact there were no UFO weapons there.Nick said: I’m sceptical about this, for a very good reason — one that’s generated a few conspiracy theories.My late father, Dr. Geoffrey Pope, was the Director of RAE Farnborough, before ending his MoD career as the Deputy Chief Scientic Adviser.As he once joked: If there was spaceship in a hangar somewhere in the UK, it would have been my hangar!BAE Warton, LancashireTheory: Next-generation aircraft developed from UFOsBAE Systems is one of the worlds biggest defence companies and Warton is its manufacturing and testing facility.Its the birthplace of some of the most innovative fighter jets ever made, including the Typhoon and the Tornado.But multiple conspiracy theorists say theyve seen UFOs flying over the airfield, sparking rumours of alien technology at the site.In fact, the MoD even had to officially deny that it had been testing its new unmanned aircraft, Taranis, after a UFO was blamed for the destruction of a wind turbine.And Nick says you only have to look at the development of cutting-edge aircraft to be confident BAE Warton has technology the public dont know about.He said: People would be staggeredthey knew how long ago stealth technology was being developed, many years before anything was officially acknowledged.The RAF’s proposed Tempest aircraft – BAE Systems is one of the partners – will be armed with lasers and hypersonic weapons, and accompanied by a drone swarm.If this is the stuff they’re telling you about, what aren’t they telling you Considering the possibility of alien technology being hidden somewhere in the UK, Nick remains sceptical well ever really know about it.He said: If Britain does have an Area , andalien secrets are being kept somewhere in the UK, my view is that while the locations I’ve mentioned are signicant, the real action will going on somewhere , at a location so secret, the media and public have never heard of it.The truth is out there… Somewhere!Nick Pope worked for the Ministry of Defence for  years. From  to  he ran its UFO project

title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. But there she was, browsing the aisles and totally unbothered by anyone.Why  Well, firstly, she wasn’t wilfully drawing attention to herself by radiating self-importance. And secondly, while she’s paid to be dramatic on screen, her le outside of it is anything but.Meaning that, in everyday le, her showbiz currency — the aforementioned “clickbait” — is, depending on how you view such things, blissfully low.But , say, she decided to dump her conservationist partner David Mills for a young barman from her local pub, a photo of her low-key shopping trip would be front-page news. Simple really.Aside from the marvellous Ms Dench, there are oodles of A- listers who live non-famous lives, popping to the supermarket or going for a low-key dinner — for example, not The Ivy et al — with loved ones.Occasionally, they might be spotted and photographed, but they just keep their head down and ignore it, accepting that it’s a small price to pay for the myriad other benefits fame brings.NDAsare now commonly used by celebrities to ensure the silence of, say, a nanny who will be privy to what happens behind closed doors — and that’s perhaps understandable.But asking a lover to sign on the dotted line when you’ve already been together two years is saying, in so many words: “I don’t trust you, but I want to carry on sleeping with you.”Who can blame Summer for telling him to stick it where the sun don’t shine Famous US basketball coach and mentor, John Wooden , once said: “Talent is God given Be humble. Fame is man-given Be grateful. Conceit is self-given Be careful.”Wise words that Mr Hollywoodwould do well to heed.WHATEVER you think of Boris Johnson’s politics, it can’t be denied that he’s working his King Ashurbanipal socks offas our new PM.Hospitals, factories, flood-hit towns – you name it, he’s popping up there to put a smile on everyone’s face and reassure them that everything is under control.He’s the frontman while the rest of the bandare putting in the hours at the studio, hopefully producing the hits. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.What on earth is happening to this country  Entire communities feel they have been abandoned by the police while criminal gangs rule by fear – and no one in power seems to know what to do about it.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. Action is what we need. And fast. Let’s hope she delivers before too many more young lives are snuffed out so brutally.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no need to ditch traditional puds
story: More than a third of young diners have never eaten a spotted dick and a quarter have never had a slice of flan, according to a study.What’s more, a fth of Brits aged  to  have never tried Eton mess, banoffee pie or rhubarb crumble — and one in six last ate jelly and ice cream TEN years ago.Traditional puds celebrate seasonal ingredients and are a pleasure to make. In winter there is nothing quite as satisfying as a steaming jam roly-poly with custard.Trle, my favourite, dates back  years. The word originally meant a light dessert, literally “a nothing”.But many desserts are disappearing from our menus.It’s not just the unfortunate overtones of roly–poly and spotted dick that are putting people off.Today, sugar, eggs, dairy and bread are out of fashion. People are opting for healthier desserts. Trendy cafes serve raw, dairy-free cakes.But I have to say “healthy dessert” is possibly the most disappointing combination of two words in the entire English language.Perhaps millennials are scared about the calories from eating out because of the growing pressure to look good on social media. If that’s the case, it’s very sad. Everything in moderation is fine.Processed food with lots of mysterious ingredients and high levels of salt and sugar is a very recent contrivance.Our grandparents ate ­simple, home-cooked meals made from fresh ingredients, and food was comparatively expensive, so people tended to eat smaller portions.Eat sensibly. You can enjoy sugar just as you might enjoy the occasional glass of wine.My kids love baking and making cakes is a great way to introduce them to cooking.Millennials are eating more fresh fruit, which is good. But food isn’t medicine. It should be something we look forward to and enjoy.Something that, eaten in moderation, will leave us feeling fully satisfied. And there are not many things that can do that for under a fiver.Here, I celebrate my favourite traditional puddings . . . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk holds the best cards brexit
story: We were warned about this before the referendum and have been told almost continuously for the past three years a British recession is just around the corner. But things aren’t quite working out that way.While the UK economy is far from booming, it is holding up much better than those in the Eurozone. Figures released yesterday show Germany’s manufacturing sector contracted by . per cent in July and is now a shocking . per cent smaller than it was a year ago.Given the importance of manufacturing to the German economy, it is likely the whole economy is now heading for recession — a fate the country only narrowly avoided at the end of last year.In Italy, too, economic growth has ground to a halt again — after the country only just hauled itself out of last year’s recession. In France, growth in the past three months fell to . per cent.By contrast, our economy looks relatively perky, with growth of . per cent in the three months to May. Figures released on Monday showed a rebound in confidence in the dominant services sector.Of the large Eurozone countries, only Spain is currently outgrowing us — but Spain is still recovering after a very deep recession from which it emerged in . In common with Italy, the Spanish economy is still smaller than it was before the - banking crisis.Not that you will hear any of this from Remainers. Every time a car factory is earmarked for closure or a steelworks runs into problems, we hear no end of people saying, “We told you so”.All bad news in the UK economy is automatically attributed to Brexit — on the BBC, especially. What we don’t hear is that manufacturing industries, especially cars and steel, are suffering the same problems across Europe.Germany’s car industry is still reeling from the scandal of Volkswagen cheating in emissions tests by installing software to detect when a car was in test mode.On top of that comes the proposed switch from petrol and diesel to electric cars. Many motorists — myself included — have put off buying new vehicles because we don’t know what to get.We have been told new petrol and diesel cars will be banned from  and worry they might be taxed out of existence well before then. Yet electric cars are still prohibitively expensive and can’t travel nearly far enough between charges.As for the steel industry, all across Europe it is struggling to compete with cheap competition from China — especially since the trade war with the US forced Chinese exporters to search for new markets away from America.Of course,we end up with a No-Deal Brexit and tarfs are imposed on imports and exports between Britain and the EU, it will cause some disruption to trade. But it is wrong to assume Britain will come off worse. In truth, EU exporters have more to lose. Britain runs a huge trade deficit with the EU.In  we exported £billion worth of goods and services to other EU countries and imported £billion from them — a trade gap of £billion. Moreover, EU exports to Britain are concentrated in products that attract relatively high tarfs.Cars, for example, attract an EU import tarf of ten per cent. If Britain chooses to impose that levy in reverse after Brexit, it will cause further mayhem in the German car industry.We also have a high deficit in food — which under EU rules attracts average tarfs of  per cent. For dairy products, the average EU import tarf is  per cent. If our Government decides to impose this on imports from the EU, it will mean the end of quite a few French cheese producers.Of course, the EU can avoid damaging these export industries by agreeing to a trade deal with the UK — one that doesn’t include the hated Irish backstop.Nearly half of Irish food exports go to the UK. Irish exports to other EU countries would be deeply affected as so many rely on UK roads. If there are delays at ports, traffic between Ireland and the Continent will suffer twice over — once crossing the Irish Sea then crossing the English Channel.EU leaders want to punish Britain for voting to leave their sacred project. They fear thatBritain is seen to do well, other countries will want to leave. But playing hardball with Britain will do deep harm to their own export industries.Does German chancellor Angela Merkel want to suffer the wrath of her country’s car makers  Does French president Emmanuel Macron wish to anger winemakers already struggling with an economic downturn at home A hard Brexit could cost Denmark as much as one per cent in lost gross domestic product. Their former economy minister Simon Emil Ammitzboll calls Brexit “the most visible threat to the Danish economy”.Holland and Belgium calculate similar falls will hit their economies, with the Dutch losing ten billion euros by . In Spain, wages for unskilled youths are lower than they were in the late s. Youth unemployment is a huge problem. Even qualied youths face a lower annual salary than their counterparts a decade ago.The alternative to all this is for the EU to swallow a bit of pride and agree to keep free trade flowing, perhaps via a temporary deal while long-term arrangements are negotiated.It won’t take much. Just remove the backstop — really just an underhand way of trying to keep Britain in the straitjacket of EU regulations and trade barriers — and some kind of withdrawal agreement would almost certainly make it through the Commons.If not, then yes, British industry will suffer in some ways from No Deal. But the Eurozone economies already lagging behind will take the bigger hit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
